Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Brain reorganization in human evolution: Connecting structural and functional changes in the inferior parietal lobe

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
During human evolution there have been large- and small-scale changes in underlying anatomical structures of the brain. Studying this reorganization is important for understanding the link between structure and function in the brain, and how this relationship may affect cognition and behavior. This project will look at changes in the interconnectedness and anatomy of a region of the brain related to planning and carrying out complex tool making, in humans and a number of non-human primate species. The findings will advance our scientific knowledge about how distinctive human behaviors originated and developed, ultimately contributing to our overall understanding of the origins of modern human behavior and culture. In addition, the project will support a female graduate student in the STEM sciences, provide science outreach to the public, and potentially inform future research on degenerative neurological diseases.

The parietal region of the brain, particularly the inferior parietal lobe (IPL), experienced reorganization in the human lineage based on studies of fossil endocasts and neuroimaging scans. The IPL is particularly active in observing, planning and executing tool-use and skilled tool-making. The proposed project will integrate histological analyses of IPL microanatomy and a neuroimaging-based study of function and connectivity between the IPL and other brain regions to investigate reorganization. These methods will be applied consistently across a sample of primate species and humans to address reorganization of the IPL in human evolution. Such an integrative approach will reveal the anatomy of the human and non-human primate IPL and will show how the IPL operates within large-scale functional networks. This study will provide a detailed investigation of human-specific changes in brain evolution within a comparative and evolutionary framework, and can aid in answering questions about the origins of distinctive human behaviors, such as complex tool-making and symbolic behaviors. Thus, studying patterns of brain reorganization in the hominin lineage ultimately contributes to our overall understanding of the origins of human behavior and culture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the brain correlates of tool-use in chimpanzees, and provide data that can be compared with humans and non-human primates. The project contained three studies that investigated tool-use in chimpanzees. Two addressed differences in gray and white matter structure that were linked with tool-use performance time in a captive sample of chimpanzees, and one focused on the histology of the inferior parietal lobe, an area associated with hand motion, object manipulation, and tool-use.

We analyzed cortical thickness and voxel-based morphometry (VBM) to detect gray matter differences associated with tool-use performance in a captive chimpanzee sample. Tool-use performance can be linked most strongly with gray matter differences in visual and motor processing areas. Both sexes exhibited increased gray matter in frontal and occipital areas associated with motor visual processing, but females showed decreased gray matter in occipital and cerebellar areas associated with basic visual processing, while males showed decreased gray matter in cortical areas associated with higher order visual processing and sensorimotor integration.

We then examined the relationship between white matter tracts and tool-use performance in the same sample of captive chimpanzees using tract-based spatial statistics (TBSS) to perform an analysis of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) metrics that indicate the properties of white matter, including fractional anisotropy (FA) and mean diffusivity (MD). There are four tracts in the human brain that are strongly involved in tool-use: the anterior thalamic radiation (ATR), inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF), superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), and the uncinate fasciculus (UF). In chimpanzees, faster tool-use performance was associated with significant clusters in the ATR, SLF, and IFOF, suggesting that white matter tracts connecting tool-related cortical areas are similar between chimpanzees and humans. Chimpanzees also had significant clusters in the corticospinal tract (CST), a tract associated with motor control that suggests differences in motor proficiency within the sample. Males exhibited a greater number of significant clusters in tracts associated with motor control such as the CST and the cerebellum than did females.

Finally, we divided, or parcellated, the chimpanzee IPL using descriptions of cellular architecture and a quantitative comparison of the identified cortical areas. Qualitative parcellations were made based on four hemispheres from two chimpanzees by observing patterns of cell distribution in the tissue to distinguish between cortical areas. In the quantitative analysis, density profiles were obtained for each cortical area and were compared using the laminar sampling method. The qualitative parcellation identified six areas in the IPL. Further examination of the density profiles of each of these areas showed that there were significant differences in layers III, IV, and V between bordering areas, supporting their classification as distinct cortical areas.

The results from this project show that chimpanzees likely have a tool-use circuit involving similar areas as in the human brain. Chimpanzees appear to rely more on areas involved in motor and visual processing for tool-use than do humans. Tool-use in chimpanzees and humans may therefore differ due to differences in the recruitment of more areas associated with cognitive control in humans, and increased connectivity between areas involved in higher order cognitive functions. Investigations of both gray and white matter showed that chimpanzees also have notable sex differences, which may be linked with previously reported differences in tool-use behaviors.

Human and chimpanzee brains must be directly compared to fully understand evolutionary changes that occurred since their last common ancestor, and it is necessary to understand the structure and function of the chimpanzee brain to ensure the validity of these comparisons. This project examines tool-use in the chimpanzee brain based on multiple modalities, and these results can form the basis of direct comparisons between chimpanzees and humans and other primate species. The results of this project can also inform paleoanthropology by through the application of the IPL cortical maps we produced to the study of endocasts. Insights into structures and cortical areas involved in chimpanzee and human tool-use can also guide morphometric studies that are seeking potential areas of expansion in the hominin lineage.

The findings of this project suggest that there may be a general tool-use circuit that is conserved across chimpanzees and humans that became increasingly specialized in the human lineage as the capacity for tools increased. These types of changes in neural circuitry associated with tool-use may underlie the variety and flexibility of the technology seen in modern human societies.

In addition to adding to our scientific knowledge base, this project also provided a means for training undergraduates in imaging and histology methods. A total of four undergraduates were trained under this project, and included students from underrepresented groups in science. Two of these undergraduates eventually became interns in the laboratory and used the skills learned from participating in this project to complete projects of their own.
